body: Would it be possible to get a call stack?

For now knowing that it's coming from a call to `glfwTerminate` call is about the best I can do. In our code, which uses a variant of PyGLFW, it gets called when the Python interpreter is exiting (by registering the ctypes wrapper of `glfwTerminate` call with `atexit.register`).

I'll be on a linux computer tomorrow (Monday) and I'll try to reproduce it. If I'm successful, perhaps I can make a minimal example, and/or do a `git bisect` on GLFW to figure it out.
I assume it was compiled for X11?

Yep, you can actually see the compilation on Travis:

https://travis-ci.org/vispy/vispy/jobs/58080099#L1627

I was able to reproduce, error is introduced somewhere here:

https://github.com/glfw/glfw/commit/49cf82a0acce513feadd8fc7d8a6ccb80e959e4e
(reproduce on an Ubuntu VM running Xvfb like Travis does, that is)
Did you have any luck getting a call stack?
What is the output of `xrandr --verbose` on either or both systems?

No call stack yet, but that command gives:

`RandR extension missing`
... do you know a good way to get the call stack?

Nevermind, I got it to dump the core using `ulimit -c unlimited`, running my code, then doing:

```
$ python -c "import nose; nose.main()" -x
...
segfault
...
$ gdb python core
...
(gdb) bt
#0  __GI___libc_free (mem=0x14b6) at malloc.c:2929
#1  0x00007ff1dab3fb88 in _glfwFreeMonitors (monitors=0x14b6, count=0)
    at /home/labsner/glfw/src/monitor.c:213
#2  0x00007ff1de3332fc in glfwTerminate () at /home/labsner/glfw/src/init.c
```

Does that help?
Wait, I think that makes sense why it might bomb actually...

Saves from a segfault when no monitors are found (e.g., when using Xvfb).

FWIW this would have been caught if some basic tests were run using Travis, as would have #225. My offer to implement some basic Travis support still stands :)
